BY MARK TRACHTENBERG
NBC correspondent Edwin
Newman, the author of two
books about abuse of the
English language, amused and
sobered a large Shriver Hall
audience Monday night with an
hour-long lecture on "Preserving
a Civil Tongue."
"Many Americans have been
cheated because they have never
had the pleasure of using language precisely and imaginatively," Newman complained.
According to Newman, the
most severe problem facing the

English language in America
today is "bloating," or redundancy.
He cited numerous
examples,including:
--A manual issued by the
Federal Aviation Administration
saying that for pilots, vertigo
has "very fatal consequences."
--A Ford commercial boasting about "new innovations."
--An NBC press release
promising there would be "twoway interaction" between Tom
Snyder and Rona Barrett.
--A CBS report referring to
"living survivors."

BY TOM GRANT
The youth Arthur drawing the
sword Excalibur from the stone, the
quest for the Holy Grail, the mysterious
and prophetic Merlin, the tragic tryst
between Lancelot and Guenevere, and the
final battle between the knights of the
Round Table and the forces of Mordred
are images which have attainted archetypal status in our culture. No fantasy is
as familiar to the English-speaking world as
the cycle of Arthurian legends, but until
now no film has fairly presented it.
Camelot lapsed into saccharine romanticism; Robert Bresson's Lancelot of the
Lake was austere and bleak to the point
of dullness; and although George Lucas
borrowed much of the mythic strength in
Star Wars from the Arthurian stories, a
derivation is definitely not the original.
John Boorman's Excalihur, a loose but
faithful adaptation of Sir Thomas
Malory's Le Morte D'Arthur, is a shining
triumph--a film which captures the
powerful essence of the Arthurian tales.
There are two major stumbling
blocks which staid in the way of filming
the Arthur story: (1) presenting the
entire legend within the time limits of a
feature-length film, and (2) telling a story
with which the audience is already
intimately familiar and making it work.
By juggling characters and events
Boorman compresses the Arthur legend
into 140 minutes, but despite the literary
sleight-of-hand necessary to do this none
of the important themes of Malory's
story are lost. Galahad's character is
deleted, and instead Perceval succeeds in
finding the Grail. The quest for the Grail
is in turn secularized into a search for
socio-political salvation rather than
religious redemption--a piece of dramatic
license which fits in better with the rest
of the narrative than Malory's sudden

gear-change into religious propagandizing.
The Grail, like Excalibur, becomes a
symbol of political authority legitimized
by supernatural powers. Incest and
adultery are still see . as politically
undermining forces, but it is Morgan le
Fay who seduces Arthur with her sorcery
and produces Mordred, rather than
Mordred being the disastrous offspring of
Arthur inadvertantly sleeping with his
aunt Margawse. Lancelot and Guenevere
have their adulterous fling, but they later
do penance for their actions and do not
cause the destruction of the Round
Table. Lancelot is a sympathetic character wishing to be purged of his love for
Guenevere, and, realizing the destructive
potential of their romance, he deliberately stays away from the court. His role
as savior is retained in Excalihur, symbolized by a wound received from falling on
his sword which parallels Christ's wound
on the cross. Details are changed in

Boorman's version of Malory, but the
underlying importance of the events and
characters is not.

Excalihur is Boorman's graphic treatment
of the story, a strange blend of realism
and fantasy. The initial scenes--craggy,
brooding castles overlooking a turbulent,
slate-grey sea; the dark figures of battling
knights silhouetted against the background of a burning town; a crowd of
grimy peasants watching jousting knights
hurling each other into the mud--are
gritty and dingy enough to be from the

representation of this period is not
historically accurate, but instead it is
what our mind's eye visualizes it to have
been. Apart from this pseudo-realism is
the element of the purely fantastic: the
armor of the Round Table knights gleams
and glistens like stainless steel; Camelot is
a fortress of silver and gold built from a
blueprint of high fantasy; Merlin creates a
prismatic spray of spells conjured out of

Rafelson, in remaining as faithful to

with a perfectionist's eye for detail, a
taut, stark drama highlighted by excellent
performances from Jack Nicholson and
Jessica Lange in the lead roles.
The story, set during the Depression, is simple, almost skeletal: Frank
Chambers (Nicholson), a drifter, stops off
at a roadside cafe run by a Greek immigrant, Nick Papadalcis (John Colicos),
and his beautiful American wife, Cora
(Lange). Enticed both by Nick's offer of
a job and his wife's sultry charm,
Chambers decides to stay on. He seduces
Cora, who is unhappy and desirous
of change, and together they plan Nick's
murder and live happily ever after, or at
least until the fates intervene. Playwright
David Mamet (Sexual Perversity in
Chicago) has supplied Rafelson with a
terse, brooding script which, while not
completely faithful to Cain's novel,
retains much of its flavor.
Rafelson (whose previous films
include Five Easy Pieces and The King of
Marvin Gardens), together with cinematographer Sven Nykvist (of Ingmar
Bergman fame), has infused each scene of
the film with a gritty, film noir look,
shooting exteriors in gray light and
interiors in half-darkness. The sets, cars,
costumes, and other incidentals are
1930's-accurate but not ostentatious,
giving the film a grimy, lived-in quality as
opposed to a back-lot gloss.

control and sensuality in the pivotal role

give her is that she more than holds her

usually dominates the screen like a
sequoia in a window box. John Colicos is
sufficiently greasy as Nick, and the
supporting players are consistently effective.

Excalibur: Mythical Reality Of Arthurian Epic
BY TOM GRANT
The youth Arthur drawing the
sword Excalibur from the stone, the
quest for the Holy Grail, the mysterious
and prophetic Merlin, the tragic tryst
between Lancelot and Guenevere, and the
final battle between the knights of the
Round Table and the forces of Mordred
are images which have attainted archetypal status in our culture. No fantasy is
as familiar to the English-speaking world as
the cycle of Arthurian legends, but until
now no film has fairly presented it.
Camelot lapsed into saccharine romanticism; Robert Bresson's Lancelot of the
Lake was austere and bleak to the point
of dullness; and although George Lucas
borrowed much of the mythic strength in
Star Wars from the Arthurian stories, a
derivation is definitely not the original.
John Boorman's Excalihur, a loose but
faithful adaptation of Sir Thomas
Malory's Le Morte D'Arthur, is a shining
triumph--a film which captures the
powerful essence of the Arthurian tales.
There are two major stumbling
blocks which staid in the way of filming
the Arthur story: (1) presenting the
entire legend within the time limits of a
feature-length film, and (2) telling a story
with which the audience is already
intimately familiar and making it work.
By juggling characters and events
Boorman compresses the Arthur legend
into 140 minutes, but despite the literary
sleight-of-hand necessary to do this none
of the important themes of Malory's
story are lost. Galahad's character is
deleted, and instead Perceval succeeds in
finding the Grail. The quest for the Grail
is in turn secularized into a search for
socio-political salvation rather than
religious redemption--a piece of dramatic
license which fits in better with the rest
of the narrative than Malory's sudden

gear-change into religious propagandizing.
The Grail, like Excalibur, becomes a
symbol of political authority legitimized
by supernatural powers. Incest and
adultery are still see . as politically
undermining forces, but it is Morgan le
Fay who seduces Arthur with her sorcery
and produces Mordred, rather than
Mordred being the disastrous offspring of
Arthur inadvertantly sleeping with his
aunt Margawse. Lancelot and Guenevere
have their adulterous fling, but they later
do penance for their actions and do not
cause the destruction of the Round
Table. Lancelot is a sympathetic character wishing to be purged of his love for
Guenevere, and, realizing the destructive
potential of their romance, he deliberately stays away from the court. His role

Chambers (Nicholson), a drifter, stops off
